class squigglepy.pdh.PDHBase[source]#

Bases: ABC

contribution_to_ev(x: ndarray | float)[source]#

Return the approximate fraction of expected value that is less than the given value.

histogram_mean()[source]#

Mean of the distribution, calculated using the histogram data (even if the exact mean is known).

histogram_sd()[source]#

Standard deviation of the distribution, calculated using the histogram data (even if the exact SD is known).

inv_contribution_to_ev(fraction: ndarray | float)[source]#

Return the value such that fraction of the contribution to expected value lies to the left of that value.

mean()[source]#

Mean of the distribution. May be calculated using a stored exact value or the histogram data.

sd()[source]#

Standard deviation of the distribution. May be calculated using a stored exact value or the histogram data.

class squigglepy.pdh.ProbabilityMassHistogram(values: ndarray, masses: ndarray, bin_sizing: Literal['ev', 'quantile', 'uniform'], exact_mean: float | None = None, exact_sd: float | None = None)[source]#

Bases: PDHBase

Represent a probability distribution as an array of x values and their probability masses. Like Monte Carlo samples except that values are weighted by probability, so you can effectively represent many times more samples than you actually have values.

binary_op(y, extended_values, ev, is_mul=False)[source]#
classmethod from_distribution(dist, num_bins=100, bin_sizing='ev')[source]#

Create a probability mass histogram from the given distribution. The histogram covers the full distribution except for the 1/num_bins/2 expectile on the left and right tails. The boundaries are based on the expectile rather than the quantile to better capture the tails of fat-tailed distributions, but this can cause computational problems for very fat-tailed distributions.

class squigglepy.pdh.ScaledBinHistogram(left_bound: float, right_bound: float, bin_scale_rate: float, bin_densities: ndarray, exact_mean: float | None = None, exact_sd: float | None = None)[source]#

Bases: PDHBase

PDH with exponentially growing bin widths.
